data.title: Column select doesn't to account for wrapped lines

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code - Insiders 1.17.0-insider (06529dbcacb796d59e7fc2ca0ac5dbe7c29c099e, 2017-09-13T09:50:23.560Z)
- OS Version: Windows_NT x64 10.0.16281
---

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Open a markdown file with lines long enough to wrap
2. Column select at the beginning of the lines
3. :bug: Cursors are added to the point where lines are wrapped

This is reproducible on 1.16 too.

<!-- Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->
Reproduces without extensions: Yes

data.title: Support git-crypt

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.15.1
- OS Version: macOS High Sierra 10.13 Beta (also on the latest version of macOS Sierra 10.12)

- Git-crypt git-crypt 0.5.0: https://www.agwa.name/projects/git-crypt/

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Clone a repository which uses git-crypt to encrypt specific files.
2. Make a small modification to one of the encrypted files.
3. Attempt to view a diff using VS Code's Source Control panel.

You will see the resulting diff shows the entire encrypted file in red, and the entire unencrypted contents of the file in green, implying the entire file has changed.

When I take a look at the Git tab of the Output console, it looks like the command being used is `git show HEAD:/path/to/filename` which doesn't seem to play nicely with git-crypt's approach. If I try something like `git diff /path/to/filename` this works as expected though.

Reproduces without extensions: Yes

data.title: Fix broken API link per vscode-docs PR #1142
data.body: See https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode-docs/pull/1142 which updated the generated vscode-api.md topic.

data.title: Terminal parsing on Windows is significantly slower due to resetting timers
data.body:
The timer is reset on a lineFeed event which happens many times during a parsing round. It looks like parsing is around 3-5 times slower than Linux/macOS because of this, dropping the framerate quite a bit.

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/2193314/30401972-f7a786e0-9890-11e7-98db-8f7227bcb2b6.png)

data.title: Allow injection grammars to specify embedded languages
keep prev. search string
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode. -->

I hope there is already existing case on such simple issue/feature

is it possible to add a drop down with list of previously completed search strings 
sometime search strings are quite lengthy and i hate simply to lose it and being forced to retype it.
as a workaround i have Notepad++ open on a side with all my searches and it just odd situation.
Pretty much any test editor out there has such feature as built-in option.

Thanks,

<!-- Use Help > Report Issues to prefill these. -->
- VSCode Version: 1.16.0
- OS Version: Windows 10
- Shell 1.7.3
- Renderer 58.0.3029.110
- Node: 7.9.0
- Arch: x64
- Hardware: Surface Pro 3


Steps to Reproduce:
1. open any text file
2. click Ctrl+F, type in string to find, Close / ESC
3. keep editing the file
4. open another tab to edit
5. click Ctrl+F, last search is gone and string to find now populated with current word from the second tab.

Suggestion: in step 5 i would like to have a drop down so i can select from history of prev. completed searches.

<!-- Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->
Reproduces without extensions: Yes

data.title: Peek feature for openNextRecentlyUsedEditorInGroup
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code 1.16.0 (787b31c0474e6165390b5a5989c9619e3e16f953, 2017-09-06T16:27:49.891Z)
- OS Version: Windows_NT x64 10.0.10586

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Hold Ctrl key.
2. Press Tab one or multiple times.

Expectation:

When a file in the recently opened list is selected, it should also switch to that file in the editor so user can peek the file content before releasing their Ctrl key. This will be the same behavior as in Sublime Text.

Since I looked around for settings and couldn't find any, I suppose this is not supported yet.

data.title: Shouldn't be possible to open the same file with different case
data.body:
VSCode Version: 1.16.0
OS Version: OSX 10.11

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Turn off preview, not sure if this is needed ("workbench.editor.enablePreviewFromQuickOpen")
2. Create file Maddog.ts
3. Rename it to maddog.ts
4. VSCode still allows to open and change both, while only one exists and **updates** when you change either file.

This is also causing havoc with typescript, can't really put my finger on what happens, feels like VSCode thinks they're both one file but TypeScript thinks they're different.

Thanks

data.title: Go to Bracket does not scroll the content to the matching bracket
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code 1.16.0 (787b31c0474e6165390b5a5989c9619e3e16f953, 2017-09-06T16:12:42.401Z)
- OS Version: Darwin x64 16.7.0
- Extensions: Extensions are disabled
---

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Create/open a JavaScript file with a long function or JSON or code block.
2. Move the cursor to an opening bracket [ or { or (.
3. Press Command+Shift+\ or select Go to Bracket from the Command Palette.

Actual result: the cursor jumps to the matching bracket, but the content does not scroll to it if it is outside the current view.

Expected result: the cursor jumps to the matching bracket, and the content scrolls to it if it is outside the current view. This is how it worked in the previous versions of Visual Studio Code.

<!-- Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->
Reproduces without extensions: Yes

data.title: Code completion (intellisense) in new Files
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.16
- OS Version: Windows 10

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Install [Python](https://marketplace.visualstudio.com/items?itemName=donjayamanne.python) extension from market place
2. Open a workspace
3. Create a new file (*do not save*)
4. Change language of file to Python
5. Start typing code, and there's no intellisense

FYI - I am fairly certain this used to work in an older version.
I've debugged this and the the ```provideCompletionItems``` method of the class implementing ```vscode.CompletionItemProvider``` is not being hit. 

Related https://github.com/DonJayamanne/pythonVSCode/issues/1194

data.title: Injection grammars with embeddedLanguages
Support autoGuessEncoding in ripgrep-based search
data.body:
Tracking autoGuessEncoding support for search. Currently ripgrep requires you to specify which encoding to search for.

Original encoding discussion is in https://github.com/BurntSushi/ripgrep/issues/1. I don't believe there's a current plan to implement this in Ripgrep.

data.title: Comments containing unbalanced brackets cause freeze when applying javascript syntax highlighting
data.body:
When applying javascript syntax highlighting to a file that contains a comment block with unbalanced brackets (eg. `[defaultOpt=undefined}`) most of VS Code freezes. The file menu bar is still usable but everything else is non-responsive.
![vscode-comment-braces-bug](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/2105302/30392423-a6b59fa2-9871-11e7-9cf3-e162cbc9b213.png)


- VSCode:
```
Version 1.16.0
Commit 787b31c0474e6165390b5a5989c9619e3e16f953
Date 2017-09-06T16:27:49.891Z
Shell 1.7.3
Renderer 58.0.3029.110
Node 7.9.0
Architecture x64
```

- OS Version: Windows 10 Enterprise 10.0.14393 Build 14393

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Copy the following code into a new file (or create a text file)
```
/**
 * I'm leaving a comment with messed up brackets
 *
 * @param {object} [defaultOpt=undefined} Jonathan's awesome  object
 */
```
2. Set the syntax highlight to javascript

Reproduces without extensions: Yes

data.title: Allow a project to be tracked with only one SCM provider.
data.body:
I just upgraded to VSCode 1.16.0, and now the SCM badge is showing 99+ even though all my changes have been committed.

I assume this is happening because I have the Hg SCM Provider (v1.1.7) installed, and as far as Hg is concerned, all the files in my project are untracked. Since my project is only using Git, however, I have no desire to track it with Hg, and I would like the badge to only show the count of files untracked/uncommitted in Git (not Hg).

I'm not sure if this is an issue with VSCode or the SCM provider. Please let me know if it's the latter, and I'll file a request with that project.

data.title: vscode should NOT use currently opened files as "the project"
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code 1.16.0 (787b31c0474e6165390b5a5989c9619e3e16f953, 2017-09-06T16:19:37.192Z)
- OS Version: Linux x64 4.10.0-33-generic
- Extensions: 

Extension|Author (truncated)|Version
---|---|---
theme-monokai-pro-vscode|mon|1.1.0



---

Steps to Reproduce:

1. given any project with tsconfig.json or .git on the root of the project
2. code -d <some/sub-directory>

**Expected**: There shouldn't be any difference to `code -d .`

**Actual**: Related features (in the example git or typescript) will not work; worse still for typescript they might cause incredibly poor experience since they give the impression "you have an error in your code" quite easily (which you don't!)

**Fun fact** if you do `code -d <some-file>` it actually works correctly! It's only directories it flops on.

<!-- Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->
Reproduces without extensions: Yes

---

VSCode git features, as well as far more annoyingly typescript features only really see the current opened file tree as "the project." This is troublesome because it means you are always forced to open the monolithic project for anything you do (unless you want those features to just break--for typescript that means errors everywhere as it's typings break).

**Why open a sub-tree?** There are many reasons, but the most important...

 - great when working with workspaces or multiple monitors (different sections of interest on different workspaces or monitors)
 - much easier to reason with when seeing a small subset (even if not split by business unit, almost all projects have a "src" section and the root is filled with garbage configuration files, or a folder where all the css is, different trees for server, client, whatnot etc)
 - sometimes for various reasons such as some sort of refactoring of files around you need multiple file trees side by side

**Desirable solution**: search up until you find the key file (ie. `.git` or `tsconfig.json`)

Alternatively a way to artificially shrink the entire tree to just the desired tree (so a UI only fix) also works but is far more inconvenient since it means you cant just do `code -d <some-folder>` and expect it to just work (the confusion for anyone unaware also persists). Honestly even just having some "key" file to tell vscode "this is the project root" is a better alternative (for typescript you can just burrow "package.json" for this purpose, ie. search up until you hit "package.json").

**Where it gets REALLY annoying** 

If you're not aware vscode is "confused" on the context of something like say "typescript," you can easily enter a state where the editor will complain about things, that actually it shouldn't complain at all. 

In my case it was related to the `.d.ts` files feature. Since it couldn't read the `tsconfig.json` it couldnt figure out where declarations I wrote were. Writing these declarations is painful enough (with all the double-triple-standards of old/new/special-god-knows-what-rules) so having the editor report "I don't know where namespace is" but understand X and Y types declared in the same place as the namespace because the file was open in the same instance of the editor (I guess type symbols it can grab with out the `tsconfig.json` but namespaces are special?) makes for quite the painful experience.

As a new user to typescript I can say this particular editor issue (for the time you're unware it's the editors fault) paints the worst image possible for the language: one of a language with a lot of nitpicky issues where nothing anyone (including the documentation) works and where common sense is severely lacking.

*And yes if you run tsc it works, but it's easy the editor confusion to send you into a loop where you add stuff to "fix it" (from your perspective) in the editor, that is clearly wrong, and hence break it in tsc, then you fix it in tsc, and now the editor complains again. Repeat (until you hopefully notice the disconnect between the two).*

data.title: Add indentationRules to lua
